newsitem.title: PANAMA: Former Panama strongman Noriega shows some heart.
newsitem.headline: Former Panama strongman Noriega shows some heart.

text.p: Panama's jailed former strongman Manuel Antonio Noriega has declined to collect a $1,500-a-month pension and asked that it be paid to a woman who helped raise him, government officials said on Thursday.

Noriega, who is serving a 40-year sentence in Florida for a 1992 conviction on drug and racketeering charges, asked social security officials to send the payments to a Panamanian caretaker who helped raise him when his mother died.

Social security officials said Noriega, who was deposed in a December, 1989 U.S. invasion, was entitled to the money after 27 years of service with the National Guard and the notorious Panama Defence Forces, which acted as his henchmen.
Panama's largest human rights group said Noriega should get a pension despite his dismal human rights record.
"Even though he has committed human rights violations, he is entitled to receive his pension," said Osvaldo Velasquez, president of Panama's Pro Human Rights Committee.
Noriega is alleged to have amassed millions of dollars in corruption and payoffs from drug dealers during his rule.
